channel.title: Proper event handling
channel.description:
Alright, so I'm trying to determine a better way of handling events, that could have millions of different permutations. An example of this would be the Item-on-Item handling on a private server. Now traditionally, people would program all of the different permutations into one block of code, with hundreds of conditionals. Now, while it may work, it's not very nice, and maintenance is a pain. Another way that has been gaining popularity is using scripts to handle it, which reduces the maintainability problem, but requires the use of another API to work, which I would like to avoid.
So what are your thoughts on a better way of handling such events?

item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:36, topic:434829”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=537546.msg3930911#msg3930911 date=1330657028]

Either way, you’re going to have to program it. My idea is: why not program less? It’s an easier approach, regardless of where you put the code. By using a domain-specific language (whether customly interpreted or defined in a dynamic language like lisp), you can specialize constructs just for handling the specific cases for each and every even permutation. It would same a lot of programming time, not to mention a large event system has a lot of resource overhead.

So you’re suggesting just programming it in the traditional way?
[/quote]

Not at all. I’m suggesting the complete opposite: use a specific language just for this problem. A language that utilizes as little text to do as much as possible, such as:

"(*) bar" on "anvil":
	first.$1 = "bronze":
		startBronzeDialogue()
	first.$1 = "rune":
		startRuneDialogue()

Etc.

Edit: As far as processing is concerned, it doesn’t matter whether it’s event-driven or not. The idea is to minimalize the complexity behind the system, which simplifies development time, collaboration time, and leads to overall less bugs and problems. I also believe Jagex may take an approach similar to this, as they often discuss their serverside “rune script” language.[/quote]Clojure would allow a pretty DSL to be made much faster than writing your own. thank heaven for macros.

I passed out a few moments shortly after that post so eh yea, should be something like… Crafting and just having all the crafting related events put into one single class. You wouldn’t need “NeedleOnItemListener” as previously stated… like the example I provided “InventoryItemOnInventoryItemListener” then -single class per event- you would have each specific item you want to add implements its appropriate listener (Maybe that is why I named it chisel lul). Then just have your impl package containing all the events. Breaking each item into its own class is an overkill as previously stated, especially if you want to replicate the whole game.

item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Rodgerwilco:

Why not interfaces?

What do you mean? If you mean something like

public interface ItemEventHandler {
    public void handleEvent(final int used, final int with);
}
public class ChiselItemHandler implements ItemEventHandler {
    @Override
    public void handle(final int used, final int with) {
        if (used != CHISEL) {
            return;
        }
        if (gems.contains(with)) {
            handleGemCut();
        }
    }
}

Then while I am breaking it up into different classes, I am also still doing it the traditional way.
